sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file has been extracted fc files in the Digital Mitford Archive.

person.note: Alberti is a character in Rienzi; Captain of the Guard. Played by Mr. Thompson as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.

Possibly a deleted character in Mitford's Charles I. Coles identifies the undated fragment in which Alice appears as having been written in July or August, 1823, although in her letter to Talfourd dated 9 November 1823 , Mitford indicates that she will delete the scene. The character does not appear in the final version of the play.
Character of the Ambassador in Rienzi. No surname given for this character.
Title character in Antigone by Sophocles.
Bertone is the character of a servant to Count D'Alba in Julian. Played by Mr. Comer as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Lord Cafarello is a character in Rienzi; one of the members of the Colonna faction. Played by Mr. Lee as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Caliban is a character in The Tempest.
Calvi is the character of a Sicilian noble in Julian.
Character of the daughter of Senator Donato in Mitford's play Foscari. Played by Mrs. Sloman as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826.
Title character in Camilla; Mitford admires Burney's characterization of her in her a letter to Elford from 30 May 1819.
Camillo is a character in Rienzi; Rienzi's servant. Played by Mr. C. Jones as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Title character in Bickerstaff's comedy The Hypocrite , a satirical version of Tartuffe by Moli√®re.
Celso is a character in Foscari; a follower of Erizzo. Played by Mr. Fitzharris as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826.
The Centinel is a character in Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Chippendale.
The character of King Charles I of England in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Abbott.
Character of the daughter of Cola di Rienzi in Rienzi. Played by Miss Phillips as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character in Rienzi, the son of Stephen Colonna. Played by Mr. Cooper as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character of the wife of Stephen Colonna in Rienzi. Played by Mrs. Faucit as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character in Rienzi, a Roman nobleman. Father of Angelo Colonna. Played by Mr. Younge as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character of Arthur's mother in The Life and Death of King John.
Character who is Solicitor to the House of Commons in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Chalk. See also the character's historical counterpart: John Cook.
Title character in Coriolanus.
Character who is the son of Senator Donato in Foscari. Played by Mr. Egerton as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826.

Character of Oliver Cromwell in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Cathcart. See also the character's historical counterpart: Oliver Cromwell, Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
Count D'Alba is the character of a powerful Noble in Julian. Played by Mr. Abbott as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Character in The Heart of Midlothian by Walter Scott, heroine and sister of Effie Deans. She walks from Edinburgh to London to secure a pardon for her sister on a charge of infanticide.
Character in Othello.
Character in Guy Mannering.
Character in Much Ado About Nothing.
Character in Mitford's play Foscari. Played by Charles Mayne Young as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826. See also the character's historical counterpart: Doge Foscari.
Title character in Don Quixote.
Character in Foscari. Played by Mr. Egerton as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826. See also the character's historical counterpart: Senator Donato.
Character in The Antiquary.

Downes is the character of a Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Bender. See also the character's historical counterpart: John Downes.
Name of idealized female character in Don Quixote who is mentioned in the text but never appears. Proverbial for an ideal woman.

person.persName: Elspeth of the Craigburnfoot of Glenallan
person.note: Character in The Antiquary.
Character of Steenie's grandmother in The Antiquary. Elspeth Mucklebackit, or Elspeth of the Craigburnfoot of Glenallan.
Count Erizzo, a character in Mitford's play Foscari. Played by Mr. Warde as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826.

Character of the General of the Parliamentary Army in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Selby. See also the character's historical counterpart: Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord Fairfax of Cameron.
Character in Shakespeare's Henry IV part one.

Character in Foscari, the son of Doge Foscari. Played by Charles Kemble as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826. See also the character's historical counterpart: Jacopo Foscari.
Character in Rienzi, a partisan of Ursini, also a nobleman. Played by Mr. Bland as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character in The Life and Adventures of Robinson Crusoe.
Character is a colonel of the Guard in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Thomas. See also the character's historical counterpart: Francis Hacker.
Title character in Hamlet.
Hammond is the character of the Governor of the Isle of Wight in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Fleming. See also the character's historical counterpart: Thomas Hammond.

A character of a Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Doyne. See also the character's historical counterpart: Major General Thomas Harrison.
Title character in Helen.
Character in Bonduca.

Sir Thomas Herbert is the character of a Gentleman attending on the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Doyne. See also the character's historical counterpart: Thomas Herbert.
Character in The Winter's Tale.
Character in Camilla; Mitford admires Burney's characterization of him in her a letter to Elford from 30 May 1819.
Character in Cymbeline.

Ireton is the character of a Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. J. Webster. See also the character's historical counterpart, who was married to Cromwell's daughter Elizabeth: Henry Ireton.
Character in Marriage; Mitford admires errier's characterization of her.
Character of the Jailer in Foscari. No surname given.
Julian is the character of the Duke of Melfi's son in Julian. Played by William Macready as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Character in Henry VIII, based on historical figure Katharine of Aragon.
The character of King Philip is the King of France in Shakespeare's King John.
Lady Fairfax is a character married to Lord Fairfax in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Miss Somerville. See also the character's historical counterpart: Anne Vere, Lady Fairfax.
A character in Lady Morgan's novel The O'Donnel's.
Character in Walter Scott's novel Kenilworth. The nephew of innkeeper Giles Gosling.
The character of Laura is Senator Donato's niece in Mitford's Foscari. Played by Miss Henry as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826.
Leanti is the character of a Sicilian Noble in Julian. Played by Mr. Egerton as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Character in Rule a Wife and Have a Wife by Beaumont and Fletcher.
Character in The Winter's Tale.
Character in Austen's novel Pride and Prejudice.
Character in Macbeth.
Title character in Macbeth.
Character in Marriage; Mitford admires Ferrier's characterization of her.
Character of a loquacious chambermaid in the farce Deaf as a Post.
Character in Camilla; Mitford says of this character that "the very name is as stiff as poker," in a letter to Elford from 30 May 1819.

Marten is the character of a Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Forrester. See also the character's historical counterpart: Henry Marten
Character in Guy Mannering.
The character of the Duke of Melfi is uncle to Alfonso, and Regent of the Kingdom of Naples in Julian. Played by Mr. Bennett as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February, 1823.
Character in The Tempest.
A character in Lady Morgan's novel Florence Macarthy.
Title character in John Gibson Lockhart's 1819 novel, Peter's Letters to his Kinfolk.
A character in Lady Morgan's novel The O'Donnel's.
Character in Marriage; Mitford admires Ferrier's characterization of her.
Character of the Nuncio in Rienzi.
Character in The Antiquary.
Character of one of the Ladies in Foscari. No surname given in the Cast List.
Title character in Othello.
Paolo is the character of Julian's servant in Julian. Played by Mr. Ley as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Character of Paolo, a Roman citizen, in Rienzi. Played by Mr. Yarnold as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character in Wheel of Fortune.
Character of a servant in Gaston de Blondeville.
Character of Count Pisani in Foscari.
The character of an Officer in the Parliamentary Army in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Addison. See also the character's historical counterpart: Thomas Pride.

Character who is a daughter of Queen Henrietta Maria and King Charles I, a girl aged twelve, in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Miss Josephine. See also the character's historical counterpart: Elizabeth Stuart.

Son of Queen Henrietta Maria and King Charles I, a boy of seven years old in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Master Norman See also the character's historical counterpart: Henry Stuart.
Character of the magician in Shakespeare's play, The Tempest.

Character of the Queen of England in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mrs. Fisher. See also the character's historical counterpart: Henrietta Maria, Queen Consort of England, Scotland and Ireland.
Character in Hamlet
Character in Glenfergus by Mudie.
Character in Ivanhoe, daughter of Isaac.
The character of the old Huntsman in Julian. Played by Mr. Mears as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Character in Rienzi. Played by Mr. Young as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828. See also the character's historical counterpart: Cola di Rienzo, Tribune of Rome.
Title character in The Life and Adventures of Robinson Crusoe.
Character in Pizarro.
Character who is an Attendant to Claudia in Rienzi. Played by Miss Pincott as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character in Ivanhoe.

A character who is a Commissioner appointed by Parliament to treat with the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. T. Lee. See also the character's historical counterpart: William Cecil, Lord Salisbury.
Squire character, a former farmer enlisted by Don Quixote in his service, from Don Quixote.
Lord Savelli is a character in Rienzi; one of the members of the Colonna faction. Played by Mr. Aitken as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.

The character of a Commissioner appointed by Parliament to treat with the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Mildenhall. See also the character's historical counterpart: William Say.
The character of the Servant belonging to Cromwell in Mitford's play, Charles I. No proper name given. Original role created by Mr. Kerridge.
Character of Sforza in Foscari. See also the character's historical counterpart: General Sforza.
Teresa is the character of an Attendant to Claudia in Rienzi. Played by Mrs. Webster as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Berta is the character of an Attendant to Claudia in Rienzi. Played by Mrs. Geesin as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.

The character of a Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. G. Williams. See also the character's historical counterpart: Robert Tichburne, Mayor of London.

Pseudonym used by Mr. Johnson. Author of A Letter to the Independent Electors of Westminster (1809), Timothy Trueman's Admonitions to the Clergy (1816), and The Curse of Gehazi (1819). Not the same as the author of the American publications The Burlington Almanac and The New Jersey Almanac, who also used this pseudonym.
Character from Dante's Inferno. Guilty of treason.
Character in Otto of Wittelsbach.
Leader of the Ursini family in Mitford's Rienzi; a Nobleman and rival to Colonna. Played by Mr. Mude as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Valore is the character of a Sicilian Noble in Julian. Played by Mr. Baker as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Annabel is the character of the wife of Julianin Julian. Played by Miss Lacy as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.

The character of a Commissioner appointed by Parliament to treat with the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Debar.See also the character's historical counterpart: Henry Vane.
Character in Coriolanus.
Character in Henry VIII.
Character of one of the Venetian Senators in Foscari. Played by Mr. Horrebow as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, November 1826.

Actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Mitford's protege in the 1830s, mentioned in her letters. She also addressed a poem to him: "On Mr. Cathcart's performance of Cromwell in the tragedy of Charles I." Macready mentions this about Cathcart's performance in Charles I: "The play is wretchedly constructed, with some powerful scenes, many passages of power and considerable effect in the sketch of Cromwell's character, which, deserving first-rate support, was consigned to the murderous Mr. Cathcart--a very poor pretender indeed." Source: The Diaries of William Charles Macready, 1833-1851, volume one.Entry for July 12, 1834, page 165." Forename unknown. More research needed.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Active 1830s. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Debuted in 1816 in Bertram at Drury Lane; she also performed at Covent Garden. She married Alfred Bunn, stage manager at Drury Lane, who succeeded the Kembles and later performed under her married name as Mrs. Bunn.
Child actor who appeared in Mitford's play, Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays, Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823 and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. In 1833, he opened the Victoria Theatre, formerly known as the Coburg, with Daniel Egerton. He also served as manager at the Haymarket Theatre and later moved to America, where he managed the New Charleston Theatre in Charleston, South Carolina, in 1837.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays, Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823; and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays: Foscari at Covent Garden Theatre in 1828; Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. He was primarily a Covent Garden actor, playing secondary characters in tragedy. He also managed the Sadler's Wells theater and the Olympic Theatre in the early 1820s. In 1833, he opened the Victoria Theatre, formerly known as the Coburg, with William Abbott. He retired the following year.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays: Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823; and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed. Active 1810s to 1830s.
Actor who appeared in Mitford's plays: Julian at Covent Garden Theatre in 1823; and Charles I at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Rienzi at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1828. Forename unknown. More research needed. Not to be confused with well-known lead actor Charles Mayne Young, who also appeared in the play.

Actress who appeared in her first professional role as Claudia in Rienzi at at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1828. Mitford intitially expressed concern over the casting of the inexperienced Miss Phillips, but later praised her for her emotionally-charged portrayal. Forename unknown. More research needed.
Actor who appeared in Rienzi at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1828. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Actor who appeared in Rienzi at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1828. The wife of actor Alfred Wigan, she later appeared as Mrs. Wigan.
Actor who appeared in Rienzi at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1828. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Musician, born in Reading, who composed the music for Mitford's opera Sadak and Kalasrade; or the Waters of Oblivion in 1835. He studied at the Royal Academy of Musicin London and was a composer and singer as well as performer on the pianoforte and organ. In 1839, he was convicted of forgery and sentenced to life transportation to the Australian colonies. He performed and took pupils at Hobart Town, Tasmania, and was conditionally pardoned in 1850. He later moved to Sydney, where he continued to perform and to compose. In 1863, his career was curtailed when he was convicted of bigamy and sentenced to five years' hard labor. While imprisoned, he continued to compose and perform and he resumed teaching and composing upon his release, although never with his previous success. His best-known work was an oratorio, Crown of Thorns, or Despair, Penitence and Pardon (1863).

Renaissance-era actor, theater manager, poet, and playwright. Part owner of playing company The Lord Chamberlain's Men and author or co-author of 38 plays. Considered the greatest English dramatist and Britain's national poet. Mitford wrote in the Introduction to her Dramatic Works: "It is the privilege of English people to grow up [ . . . ] in the worship of Shakespeare, and many of his favourite scenes I literally knew by heart."
German playwright, author of the tragedy Otto von Wittelsbach.
House of Wittelsbach, Bavaria, known as "Otto the Illustrious;" historical figure who is the subject of Otto von Wittelsbach and Otto of Wittelsbach.
Scottish clergyman and playwright, author of the tragedy Douglas.

English journalist, novelist, editor, amateur artist, and lecturer. He wrote for Fraser's Magazine and Punch, wrote book reviews for The Times, and later edited the Cornhill Magazine. Author of the novels Vanity Fair, Pendennis, The Newcomes and The History of Henry Esmond. One of the most recognizable literary celebrities of the mid-Victorian period, after Charles Dickens. As did Dickens, he lectured in both Britain and the United States.

bibl.title: Douglas: A Tragedy
bibl.author: John Home
bibl.note: First performed in 1756in Edinburgh, followed by a performance in London in 1757. Continued to be performed professionally through the nineteenth century and the speech beginning "My name is Norval" became a favorite among amateur reciters.

bibl.title: Otto von Wittelsbach
bibl.author: Joseph Marius Babo
bibl.note: First performed in 1782. German tragedy based on the life of Otto II of Wittelsbach; Mitford based her play on the same subject on this tragedy. Babo's play was first translated into English in 1800by Benjamin Thomson as Otto of Wittelsbach, or, The Choleric Count: A Tragedy in Five Acts.

bibl.title: Specimens of English Dramatic Poets, Who Lived About the Time of Shakespeare. With Notes
bibl.author: Charles Lamb

bibl.title: Lectures Chiefly on the Dramatic Literature of the Age of Elizabeth, Delivered at the Surry Institution
The Oxford English Dictionary Online
bibl.note: Multi-volume descriptive dictionary of the English language, first published in 1884. Online version launched in 2000 includes ongoing updates to the third edition.

bibl.title: Introduction [to the Dramatic Works]
bibl.note: Introduction, first published in The Dramatic Works of Mary Russell Mitford; not published separately elsewhere.

bibl.title: The History of Pendennis: His Fortunes and Misfortunes, His Friends and His Greatest Enemy
